body:
## Problem
`exit_timeout` don't work when quit neovim

`pkill emmylua_ls; VIMRUNTIME=runtime/ nvim --clean -u repro.lua repro.lua ; waitpid $(pgrep emmylua_ls)`

```
vim.lsp.config('foo', { cmd = { 'emmylua_ls' }, exit_timeout = 1000 })
vim.lsp.enable('foo')
vim.defer_fn(vim.cmd.quit, 500)
```

## Solution
wait in VimLeavePre

comment_data.body: Waiting forever (`math.huge`) is not correct. It should wait until `exit_timeout` (if it's a number), that is the entire purpose of `exit_timeout` ?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1155,6 +1155,12 @@ api.nvim_create_autocmd('VimLeavePre', {
     for _, client in pairs(active_clients) do
       client:stop(client.exit_timeout)
     end
+
+    vim.wait(math.huge, function()
+      return vim.iter(active_clients):all(function(client)
+        return client._shutdown_timer == nil

comment_data.body:
~change it to wait for max `exit_timeout` of all client. f17a3824d77be08fd2fedce2a747666f06b42a30~

No, this don't fix issue in repro.lua. Use `max_timeout + 1` can fix but not sure if can also work for other case.

comment_data.body:
It is probably worth showing a message here.

```suggestion
    if max_timeout > 10 then
      vim.api.nvim_echo(...)
    end
    vim.wait(max_timeout + 1, function()
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1152,9 +1152,19 @@ api.nvim_create_autocmd('VimLeavePre', {
     local active_clients = lsp.get_clients()
     log.info('exit_handler', active_clients)
 
+    local max_timeout = 0
     for _, client in pairs(active_clients) do
       client:stop(client.exit_timeout)
+      if type(client.exit_timeout) == 'integer' then
+        max_timeout = math.max(max_timeout, client.exit_timeout)
+      end
     end
+
+    vim.wait(max_timeout + 1, function()

comment_regular_data.body: Unfortunately this leads to memory leaks...

See #36752 for prior discussion. I've thought about good solutions to this problem on and off for a while now, and all of them have tradeoffs that I'm unhappy with. Still unsure what the best way to solve this bug is.

The options are to block vim on exit, force quit the language server (what we do now), or detach the server on exit. All three of which are bad in their own ways.

> The options are to block vim on exit, force quit the language server (what we do now), or detach the server on exit. All three of which are bad in their own ways.

If the user explicitly set `exit_timeout` then they have explicitly asked Nvim to wait on exit. That was the intended purpose of the field, right?

The [default of exit_timeout=false](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/36752#issuecomment-3596017419) does _not_ wait, so by default Nvim will exit immediately.

Does this PR conform to the above? @phanen

> If the user explicitly set exit_timeout then they have explicitly asked Nvim to wait on exit. That was the intended purpose of the field, right?

Correct. Back when it was an experimental `flags.exit_timeout`, that was its only purpose, although (afaik) it did not actually function and always behaved as if `exit_timeout=true` on exit.

> Does this PR conform to the above?

Yes. `exit_timeout=true/integer` sigterm lsp immediately or after a timeout when we cannot stop the server by "shutdown" request.
This pr force nvim to keep alive to execute possible pending sigterm.

I'm not sure why `exit_timeout` was invented (maybe to handle some buggy lsp? but why nvim won't kill all its chlidren automatically on quit), I use it to avoid some dangling lsp. `exit_timeout=false` we only emit "shutdown" request.
I'm not sure if this callback can always executed when it quit nvim.
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/9278f792c374e32de4906dc23adfc9144812c285/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/client.lua#L900-L908

Even it's executed, sometime lsp don't succefully quit (like repro.lua I post above). So have to set `exit_timeout` to force it stop.

> although (afaik) it did not actually function and always behaved as if `exit_timeout=true` on exit.

I think it behave as `exit_timeout=false`, it sent "shutdown" request but it don't sigterm the lsp.

> but why nvim won't kill all its chlidren automatically on quit)

Waiting for children to exit takes time, X seconds or much longer, then users complain about it. 

> `exit_timeout=false` we only emit "shutdown" request.

Correct, and that should be enough to stop any non-buggy LS.

But if `exit_timeout>0` then Nvim should wait up to that timeout. Are we not doing that? The current approach in this PR doesn't look right. 

The correct behavior is that Nvim waits up to `exit_timeout` milliseconds. Are we doing that or not?

> But ifÂ `exit_timeout>0` then Nvim should wait up to that timeout. Are we not doing that?

Currently, Nvim does not wait. That's the bug in #36752. I believe the logic is to prevent Nvim from seemingly "freezing" while it's waiting for a  language server to exit.
cc @mfussenegger since you've been involved in this discussion in the past.

> Currently, Nvim does not wait. That's the bug in #36752. I believe the logic is to prevent Nvim from seemingly "freezing" while it's waiting for a language server to exit.

That is the reason for the `false` default. But if the user opts-in to a non-`false` `exit_timeout`, then they have explicitly requested to wait up to that maximum for LS to exit, on Nvim exit.

This PR looks ok but the CI failure is obviously a blocker.

> That is the reason for the `false` default. But if the user opts-in to a non-`false` `exit_timeout`, then they have explicitly requested to wait up to that maximum for LS to exit, on Nvim exit.

Makes sense. It's still unideal that `false` behaves as `true` during Nvim exit, but at least making things work as expected when `exit_timeout` is a number is a good start.

> It's still unideal that `false` behaves as `true` during Nvim exit

Agh ð :) It's somewhat defensible because it aligns with `stop(force:boolean)`. But yes, we need to document `exit_timeout` to mention the "Nvim exit" behavior.

Alternatively, if there were an easy way for users to call `stop()` on all servers, we could just document that and avoid all this (which is getting too subtle) + the CI failure...
